properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 10 at 2:10PM EST until February 11 at 3:34PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
...A Flood Warning continues for portions of the following waterways
in Indiana...

Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Eel River...Mississinewa
River...Wabash River...White River...Youngs Creek...


.Precipitation of up to about 2 inches fell Sunday into Monday,
heaviest within 50 miles north and south of Interstate 70 across
the state.  Flooding is expected to occur at several locations on the
Wabash River from Montezuma southward, and on the White River from
Centerton southward.  Flooding along the lower reaches will last past
February 20.

The latest forecast model data is predicting flood crests to
generally be close to, but probably slightly below, what we saw in
January.  Crests along the White River are expected to come close to
moderate flood state at Spencer, Elliston, Newberry, and Edwardsport.
County, state, and federal roads and some river cabins may be
impacted.  In addition, a few homes in Waverly may be affected. The
Mississinewa River near Ridgeville will come near or perhaps onto
State Road 1 near State Road 28.

Flooding on the Driftwood River is expected to last no more than a
couple days.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississinewa River near Ridgeville.
* until Tuesday afternoon.
* At 1:00 PM Monday the stage was 12.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.0 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It will rise to near 12.6 feet by this afternoon then
begin falling. It will fall below flood stage Tuesday morning.
* At 13.0 feet...Significant flooding of Mississinewa River in
northern Randolph County.  Water is likely on SR 1 just south of SR
28.  West CR 825 N east of SR 1 and West River Road west of SR 1
and possibly other county roads are flooded.  Little League field
in Ridgeville is flooded.  Noticeable agricultural flooding in
progress.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
